description: A sample project to demonstrate the RALPH loop

stories.title: Create hello world script
stories.description: Create a simple hello.sh script that prints 'Hello, RALPH!'

steps.text: hello.sh file exists
Script is executable (chmod +x)
Running ./hello.sh prints 'Hello, RALPH!'

stories.title: Add greeting function
stories.description: Add a greet() function to hello.sh that takes a name parameter and prints 'Hello, {name}!'

steps.text: greet() function exists in hello.sh
greet 'World' outputs 'Hello, World!'
greet 'Alice' outputs 'Hello, Alice!'

stories.title: Add timestamp to greeting
stories.description: Modify the greet function to include the current timestamp in the output

steps.text: greet function includes timestamp in output
Timestamp format is human-readable
Running greet 'Test' shows current time

stories.title: Add farewell function
stories.description: Add a farewell() function to hello.sh that takes a name parameter and prints 'Goodbye, {name}! See you soon.'

steps.text: farewell() function exists in hello.sh
farewell 'World' outputs 'Goodbye, World! See you soon.'
farewell 'Alice' outputs 'Goodbye, Alice! See you soon.'

stories.title: Add color support
stories.description: Add color output support to hello.sh. Greetings should be green, farewells should be yellow. Add a --no-color flag to disable colors.

steps.text: greet output is green when run in terminal
farewell output is yellow when run in terminal
Running with --no-color flag disables colors

stories.title: Add help command
stories.description: Add a --help flag to hello.sh that displays usage information showing all available functions and flags.

steps.text: Running ./hello.sh --help displays usage information
Help text lists greet and farewell functions
Help text mentions --no-color flag

stories.title: Add logging to file
stories.description: Add a --log flag that appends all greetings and farewells to a hello.log file with timestamps.

steps.text: Running greet with --log creates/appends to hello.log
Log entries include timestamp and message
farewell with --log also logs to hello.log

stories.title: Add count flag
stories.description: Add a --count N flag that repeats the greeting or farewell N times.

steps.text: greet 'World' --count 3 outputs the greeting 3 times
farewell 'World' --count 2 outputs the farewell 2 times
Default count is 1 when flag is not provided

stories.title: Add uppercase flag
stories.description: Add a --uppercase flag that outputs the greeting or farewell in all uppercase letters.

steps.text: greet 'World' --uppercase outputs 'HELLO, WORLD!'
farewell 'World' --uppercase outputs 'GOODBYE, WORLD! SEE YOU SOON.'
Flag works combined with other flags like --no-color

stories.title: Add version flag
stories.description: Add a --version flag that displays 'hello.sh version 1.0.0'.

steps.text: Running ./hello.sh --version displays 'hello.sh version 1.0.0'
Version flag exits immediately without running other commands
Help text mentions --version flag

stories.title: Add random greeting mode
stories.description: Add a --random flag that picks a random greeting style (Hello/Hi/Hey/Greetings) instead of always using 'Hello'.

steps.text: greet 'World' --random outputs one of: 'Hello, World!', 'Hi, World!', 'Hey, World!', or 'Greetings, World!'
Running multiple times with --random produces varied output
Help text documents the --random flag

stories.title: Add quiet mode
stories.description: Add a --quiet flag that suppresses timestamp output even when timestamps are normally shown.

steps.text: greet 'World' --quiet outputs greeting without timestamp
farewell 'World' --quiet outputs farewell without timestamp
Help text documents the --quiet flag

stories.title: Add custom delimiter
stories.description: Add a --delimiter flag that changes the comma separator to a custom string. Default is ', '.

steps.text: greet 'World' --delimiter ' - ' outputs 'Hello - World!'
farewell 'World' --delimiter ': ' outputs 'Goodbye: World! See you soon.'
Default delimiter remains ', ' when flag is not used

stories.title: Add batch mode from file
stories.description: Add a --file flag that reads names from a file (one per line) and greets/farewells each one.

steps.text: greet --file names.txt greets each name in the file
farewell --file names.txt farewells each name in the file
Error message shown if file doesn't exist

stories.title: Add JSON output mode
stories.description: Add a --json flag that outputs the greeting/farewell as JSON instead of plain text.

steps.text: greet 'World' --json outputs valid JSON with type, name, message, and timestamp fields
farewell 'World' --json outputs valid JSON with type 'farewell'
JSON output can be piped to jq without errors
